Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Can finite verbs agree in number with a nominal object?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Comment: Instances of agreement in case can not be attested.

Name: Is there non-agreement between an adnominal property word and the head noun?
Comment: Instances of agreement in case can not be attested.

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can non-finite clauses use a special means for core argument (S/A) marking?
Comment: One of the options is to express the subject of non-finite clause by an overt NP in oblique.

Name: Can non-finite clauses use a special means for core argument (P) marking?
Comment: P is marked in the same way in finite and non-finite clauses.

Name: Do characteristics of the object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Comment: However, only very few nouns distinguish between nominative and oblique in non-possessed forms, where properties of the object can be a decisive factor. For marking in the verb, topicality of the object is the most important factor.

Name: Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Does object marking depend on the verb conjugation form?
Comment: In imperative clauses, the object is usually encoded with the nominative. However,  also accusative marking can be found, which could be Russian influence as such marking cannot be attested in the speech of previous generations.

Name: Is there differential subject marking?
Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e., act as a syntactic pivot?
Comment: "Irrespective of whether a clause is active or passive, its subject can be omitted if its referent is identical with that of the subject referent of the preceding clause."

Name: Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e., act as a syntactic pivot?
Is there grammatical marking of habituality?
Comment: Habitual is used to express a regular event.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of frequentativity?
Is there grammatical marking of progressivity?
Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Comment: This needs further research.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of the immediate future?
Is there grammatical marking of pluperfect?
Comment: The aorist has no overt morpheme; the basic form of aorist refers to the past with perfective verbs.

Name: Can aspect be expressed overtly in the negative marker?
Can tense be expressed overtly in the negative marker?
Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Comment: The mirative interpretation is an extension of the perfect.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of a desire or wish?
Comment: There might have been a desiderative mood once.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to irrealis?
Comment: The subjunctive "expresses a hypothetical event with the basic tense-modal series, and an irrealis event with the past TM-series". Subjunctive is common in Forest Enets, very rare in modern Tundra Enets.

Name: Are verbs marked in a non-indicative mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Comment: An analytic construction consisting of a conditional converb of the auxiliary with anterior participle is used.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Comment: Debitive also expresses reference to the future.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Comment: The probabilitive and interrogative can be used in this function.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Comment: The soft imperative is used to express mild commands.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb used to direct commands/wishes, etc. to the 3Sg?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to direct commands/wishes, etc. to the 1Sg?
Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there a reflexive conjugation?
Comment: It is not reflexive in meaning, but traditionally called so.

Name: Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Comment: Plural or dual object in 2DU and 3DU are both marked by -ziʔ.

Name: Can the 3rd person plural verb form and impersonal (passive) verb form be encoded in the same way?
Are 2nd singular verb forms commonly used with a generic meaning?
Can an infinitival verb form be used in a directive function?
Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be in the bare infinitive form?
Comment: With the verbs of motion, the converb or supine is used, while with other verbs the converb is used.

Name: Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments?
Comment: There are verbs which can never have an overt argument, and those which can be used with and without an overt argument.

Name: Is a copula commonly used for predicate nominals in the 3rd person singular forms of the present tense?
Is a copula commonly used for predicate nominals in the past tense?
Can locative constructions commonly occur without a copula?
Comment: Locative clauses are formed with copulas ɛ-/ŋa-.

Name: Is the same coordinating conjunction commonly used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Does existential negation have a special negator?
Comment: dʲagu- 'be absent(IPFV)'

Name: Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Comment: Clausal negation involves a negative verb + a lexical verb in the non-finite connegative form.

Name: Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Comment: There is a negative anterior participle (see also UT058).

Name: Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Are there non-finite forms specializing in the relativization of particular core participants, e.g., subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Comment: Passive anterior participle (-duuj) relativizes objects, for all other participles there are frequency tendencies, not strict specializations.

Name: Are there non-finite forms that can relativize at least all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some non-core participants?
Comment: All participles are unoriented, except passive anterior participle. (The perfective participle has two allomorphs: -iʔ and -miʔ).

Name: Are there non-finite forms that can relativize at least some non-core participants but cannot relativize all or some of the core participants?
Comment: Relativization of participants other than subject and object is possible but very rare.

Name: Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negative marker?
Comment: The respective participle is called negative anterior participle.

Name: Is there a future participle?
Comment: The posterior participle can be used to express future.

Name: Are there participles that can encode their subject with possessive suffixes?
Are there participles that must agree with the nouns they modify in case and number in all contexts?
Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs?
Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Comment: Both OV and VO are present; OV could be more frequent, but a separate study is needed.

Name: Is it pragmatically neutral to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Comment: Only an adverb, a personal pronoun in the accusative form, or a non-finite complement verb may stand between negative and lexical verbs, though this happens very rarely. All examples with accusative personal pronoun and a negative imperative verb show the O NEG V-CNG order in the corpus.

Name: Are there preverbs?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Can modifiers of action nominalizations in agent and patient roles both be encoded like possessors?
Can the modifier of action nominalizations in the patient role be encoded like the direct object?
Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Comment: In the predicative position, the stative intransitive verb behaves like a verb.

Name: Is there morphological superlative marking on the property word?
Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Comment: However, there are postpositions that have never been attested with posessive suffixes.

Name: Are there adpositions that show a tripartite system?
Is there case compounding?
Are there morphological cases only used with pronouns?
Comment: Pronouns have three core cases (NOM, GEN, ACC), while nouns have only two (NOM and OBL).

Name: Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals greater than 1?
Comment: Occasionally also plural is attested.

Name: Is there a dedicated case that expresses indirect object/recipient/goal (different from a local case)?
Comment: See UT086.

Name: Is there a dedicated case that expresses a terminative meaning?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the absence of a referent (abessive)?
Comment: However, the caritive does not combine with possessive suffixes and personal pronouns, and it does not have number forms.

Name: Is there a dedicated case that expresses motion along or by a referent (prolative)?
Is there a locative case that expresses goal?
Comment: Dative marks goal and other meanings, e.g., recipient, beneficiary, etc.

Name: Is there a locative case that expresses location?
Comment: Locative also has other usages.

Name: Is there a locative case that expresses source?
Comment: Ablative also has other usages.

Name: Is there case syncretism for goal and location marking?
Is there case syncretism for location and source marking?
Are there two sets of local cases?
Are there three or more sets of local cases?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniement (comitative)?
Comment: Locative is also used in instrumental and comitative functions.

Name: Is there a case that expresses instrument (instrumental), which is different from a case that expresses accompaniment (comitative)?
Comment: Locative is also used in instrumental and comitative functions.

Name: Is there a dedicated case that expresses the result of a change (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Comment: The translative is a recent grammaticalization. It is not formed from the stem but from the nominative. The translative does not take possessive suffixes and it is not attested with peronal pronouns.

Name: Is there a case that expresses the result of a change (translative), which is different from a case that expresses a state of being (essive)?
Comment: There is no separate case. The case is referred to as the essive-translative case.

Name: Is there morphological marking dedicated to the expression of equativity?
Comment: There is only a similative suffix.

Name: Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Is there (in addition to the basic declension) a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use the singular with paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Comment: Plural is used.

Name: Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Comment: Both nominative as well as oblique can be used to encode nominal possessors.

Name: Can the possessor in the attributive construction be encoded with the nominative?
Is non-singular possession marked in the possessive declension?
Can a 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Can a 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Comment: 3SG possessive suffixes are used less commonly than 2SG possessive suffixes.

Name: Is there a human vs. non-human distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
Comment: The pronoun ʃee 'who' is also used for bear, but it is an exception. For all other non-human referents ɔbu 'what ' is used.

Name: When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for animates other than humans?
Comment: Relative clauses usually occur before the head noun in the NP.

Name: When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for inanimates?
Comment: Relative clauses usually occur before the head noun in the NP.

Name: Can a demonstrative stem be used in the function of a pronoun with a 3Sg human referent?
Are there possessive suffixes the position of which can vary in relation to case/number suffixes?
Comment: The order becomes apparent from locative forms, and the order is fixed. Core cases (i.e. NOM and OBL) are always fused with possessive forms.

Name: Is the order of number and case suffixes the same across the paradigm?
Comment: The oder becomes apparent from dual forms, whereas singular and plural possession is expressed cumulatively.

Name: Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Comment: See UT113.

Name: Are there different words for younger and older relatives for relations other than siblings?
Is there an animacy distinction for both concepts: 'new/young' and 'old'?
Is there a distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' depending on whether reference is to weather or the temperature of objects?
Is there contrastive length for consonants?
Is there contrastive length for vowels?
Comment: Enets has double or long vowels. However, cf. Helimski (1984), who analyses them as a sequence of two identical vowel phonemes.

Name: Is there a contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Is there a contrast in the length of geminate consonants?
Comment: Nonphonemic.

Name: Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Are there extralong syllables?
Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Comment: There are some affixes that tend to be prominent.

Name: Is there fixed primary stress?
Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Is there non-initial primary stress?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there velar vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
Are there closing diphthongs?
Are there opening diphthongs?
Is there a qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Is there a high front rounded vowel /y/?
Is there a mid-high front rounded vowel /ø/?
Is there a high back unrounded vowel /ɯ ɨ/?
Comment: Not a phoneme.

Name: Is there a mid-high back unrounded vowel /ɤ ɘ/?
Is there a low back rounded vowel /ɒ/?
Is there a contrast between mid front vowels (/e/ or /ɛ/) and low front vowels (/æ/ or /a/)?
Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Are there word-internal consonant clusters in the syllable onset?
Are there consonant clusters in the syllable coda?
Are there word-internal intervocalic clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there palatalized alveolar consonants?
Are there palatalized labial and velar consonants?
Is there a palatal stop?
Is there a palatal nasal /ɲ/?
Is there a palatal lateral /ʎ/?
Is there a velar nasal /ŋ/?
Is there an alveolar affricate /t͡s/?
Is there a non-alveolar affricate (e.g., /t͡ʃ/, /t͡ɕ/)?
Is there a phonological contrast between an unvoiced alveolar sibilant /s/ and an unvoiced postalveolar sibilant /ʃ/?
Are there voiced plosives (e.g., /b g d/)?
Is there a glottal stop /ʔ/?
Is there a phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g., /k/ vs. /kʷ/)?
Is there a constraint on the word-initial alveolar trill /r/?
Is there a laryngeal fricative /h/?
Is there a voiced velar fricative /ɣ/?
Comment: Appears as an allophone.

Name: Is there a voiceless velar fricative /x/?
Is there a voiced dental fricative /ð/?
Comment: Very frequent as an allophone.

Name: Is there a labio-velar approximant /w/?
Is there a voiceless labiodental fricative /f/?
Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
